awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in DRMS: Where Does Innovation Come From? Exploring the Dynamic Processes of Organizing and Managing Social Entrepreneurship and Innovation
awd_abstract_narration:
The past several decades have witnessed a significant rise in social entrepreneurship (SE) activities aimed at solving complex social problems like poverty and educational inequality. This Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant (DDRIG) will use large-scale datasets to systematically summarize the current state of SE in the United States and identify mechanisms underlying innovative social ventures. Best practices identified in the research will offer tangible solutions to help practitioners make marked improvement in creating scalable and sustainable social innovations. The research will also identify the role public policy may play in encouraging social ventures to adopt appropriate business models, employ information and communication technologies (ICTs), and engage in collaboration networks.

The research will involve surveying 3,000 social ventures across the United States to examine how market logics and community logics enable or constrain the type, degree, and quality of social innovations created by social ventures. Market logics suggest that social ventures may act like for-profit businesses and compete in capital markets to earn profits. At the same time, social ventures may also follow community logics by adopting the key principles of nonprofit organizing. The data will also be used to understand how market logics and community logics influence social ventures' use of information and communication technologies (ICTs) and inter-organizational networks to create social innovations.

por.por_cntn:
Jiawei Sophia Fu has completed research for her dissertation ?Where Does Innovation Come From? Exploring the Dynamic Processes of Organizing and Managing Social Entrepreneurship and Innovation? supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. Using large-scale, U.S-based survey data, the project focused on social ventures: nonprofit and for-profit organizations with a social mission (including social enterprises and benefit corporations). As an organizational scholar, Fu sought to understand how social ventures could develop social innovations to tackle the grand challenges of our era, such as climate change and economic inequality.

The project focused on how social ventures manage the competing demands of market and social mission in their innovations. The need to survive dictates that such organizations compete to earn profits to some extent. At the same time, social ventures must also follow social logics to achieve the organizational mission. Fu explored the interplay of these forces and how they affected organizations? use of information and communication technologies (ICTs) and their collaborations with other organizations.

During her funding period, Fu conducted two surveys with social ventures. In Study 1, she collected data from 305 501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations. Findings showed that organizations that were the most innovative had (1) developed robust collaborative partnerships, (2) regularly used ICTs, and (3) were proactive and willing to take risks. In Study 2, she collected data from 319 501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations, social enterprises, and benefit corporations. Using the survey data, Fu developed and tested a measurement scale of how organizations perceive the (1) conflict and (2) importance of social and market logics for their organization. Applying the scale, Fu found that social ventures that(1) prioritize social logics over market logics and (2) consider social and market logics competing are mostly likely to develop novel and useful social innovations.

During her grant period, Fu engaged deeply with communication, management, network science, social entrepreneurship, and ICTs scholarship. To maintain relevance of the research, she worked with three program officers from institutions and foundations that fund social entrepreneurship to evaluate the social innovations developed by these organizations. Fu developed benchmarking reports and recommendations for each participating organization to help them be more innovative. For a wider audience, including the general public and policy makers, she wrote blog posts and created infographics depicting her major findings in an accessible style.

Intellectual merit. This project makes several major theoretical contributions to current scholarship in social entrepreneurship, management, organization studies, network science, and information systems. First,this researchdraws on large-scale data sets to explore social entrepreneurship, a subject mainly examined in qualitative studies, frequently case studies. Second, the new measurement scale can be used in future quantitative research to examine the influence of institutional complexity and hybridity on organizational behavior. Third, by examining the relationship between institutional complexity and organizational innovation, this research contributes to our understanding of how different organizations respond to plural institutional logics. It thus advances a contingency theory of institutional complexity and hybridity. Finally, while previous research on innovation in business primarily focuses on product and technological innovation, this projectsheds light on theorganizational, technological, structural, and institutional factors that contribute to social innovation for social venture. Expert rating on the novelty and quality of social innovations sheds light on how institutional funders perceive social innovations and what aspects of innovation they value to inform practice.

Broader impacts. Because it uses large-scale data sets to systematically summarize the current state of social entrepreneurship in the United States,this project adds to our understanding of what makes social ventures successful. Many social ventures can benefit from the best practices identified here and improve their progress towards their respective missions. This research also suggests that governments and other institutional funders should invest in social ventures? adoption of business models, development of collaboration networks, and use of ICTs. Finally, the graduate Co-PIandfive undergraduate and graduate students have gained extensive experience and valuable interdisciplinary training in survey research.

Fu?s dissertation has won several awards, including the W. Charles Redding Dissertation Award from the Organizational Communication division of the International Communication Association and Best Paper Award and Best Social Entrepreneurship Award from the Entrepreneurship Division of the Academy of Management.
